Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phylogenomics of Cypridinidae (Ostracoda): Evolutionary origins of bioluminescence and complex behavioral displays
Award.AbstractNarration:
How complex traits and behaviors originate and diversify during evolution is a major question in biology. Bioluminescence, the production of light by living organisms, occurs in many different animal taxa. Marine ostracods, tiny shrimp-like crustaceans, use light for both avoiding predators and for behavioral displays. Over 64 bioluminescent flashing patterns have been observed throughout the Caribbean but only one third of the species have been collected and described scientifically. The proposed research will bring together a group of collaborators from institutions in Wisconsin and California to investigate the diversity of bioluminescent ostracods in the Caribbean and address how bioluminescence and complex behavioral displays have evolved within the group. Research will involve students and faculty at multiple stages in their careers, archivists of digital and morphological materials, and members of the science education media. The timing of this research is especially crucial as the assembled team of researchers includes two emeritus experts on bioluminescent ostracods who will participate in field collections and taxonomy workshops. The products of this research will include a diverse group of newly trained undergraduate and graduate students, a large comprehensive data set of newly described species that will be shared publically through museum and online curation, advancement in the bioinformatic analysis of transcriptome DNA and behavioral traits, and a better understanding of the link between genetics and complex trait evolution.

This collaborative project by researchers at the University of Wisconsin - La Crosse, California State University - Los Angeles, and University of California - Santa Barbara will use a diverse set of complimentary techniques to investigate phylogenetic relationships within Cypridinidae and the evolution of bioluminescence and complex behavioral displays. Specific aims are: 1) to reconstruct a new data rich phylogeny of Cypridinidae based on transcriptome datasets from 71 different species, 2) calculate divergence times and diversification rates within the group, 3) test for correlation between bioluminescent behavioral displays and diversification rates, and 4) investigate the molecular evolution of luciferase, the protein that catalyzes the light reaction. Understanding the biochemical origins and properties of luminescent chemicals is important because cypridinid luciferases are widely used as reporter genes in molecular biology and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On moonless nights throughout the Carribbean Sea, tiny crustaceans called cypridinid ostracods or 'sea fireflies', produce bioluminescent displays similar to terrestrial fireflies. The diversity of these displays is amazing, as there are dozens of species, each with a different display. These species and their beautiful displays are under threat of climate change and light pollution and yet science is still finding many new species, indicating there is much diversity left to discover.

This award allowed collaborating researchers to learn about the diversity, genetics, and evolution of these amazing animals.

A significant result from this research is that, sea fireflies along other animals that use bioluminescent courtship, have more species than their close relatives. This is consistent with the long-debated evolutionary hypothesis that when species have traits that cause males to compete for mating, that more biodiversity may result.

Another significant result is significant progress in understanding the evolutionary relationships of the group. In addition to discovering several new species and documenting their luminous displays with underwater cameras, the research showed that bioluminescent courtship probably evolved a single time in sea fireflies. Furthermore, there are three major groups of sea fireflies that map to taxonomic genera.

Another major result was to begin to understand how the biochemistry of light production relates to the diversity of the bioluminescent courtship signals. In particular, the courtship signals change during evolution by changing the biochemistry of light production as well as by changing how much of the components of the reaction are used to create the displays.

Finally, another result was to discover new genetic sequences of genes that produce light, called luciferases. Previously known genes from related species are already used in biomedical assays. The newly discovered genes could be used in similar ways, with slightly different biochemical properties related to how quickly and brightly they produce light.

This work also had broder impacts, providing integrative training for undergraduate and graduate students and collaborations among differently sized institutions. The PIs held a training workshop on taxonomy of this group and transferred knowledge from a generation of retiring specialists to a new generation of researchers.
